item.title: Rural Newda in Rural Vekllei
item.description: Newda is Veklleiâ€™s national architectural ideology, applied flexibly in a range of modernist styles developed domestically in her architecture schools. Broadly, Newda buildings emphasise distinction from the surrounding landscape (called Dumousiantopet, or â€˜beautiful and seperateâ€™), natural decay, and honesty in material and construction. Veklleiâ€™s great Parliament House is Newda; as are the little rural homes found in the mountains inland in Vekllei. Tziporaâ€™s house in the village of Montre-Lola ( as depicted on the map here) is built in what Vekllei calls â€œAzores revivalismâ€, a Newda style heavily influenced by the stripped deco and streamline moderne buildings of a century prior.

item.title: 2031 Apartment Diagram
item.description: Baron had inherited the apartment from his uncle, who passed in the year following his parents. It was in a mixed residential-industrial neighbourhood, adjacent to a canvas factory. Out back was a rivulet, which roared in the long rainstorms of early April. Each January, the Colour Bureau of the Architecture Assembly announces the yearâ€™s colours, and tradition in mainstream architecture and interior design is to incorporate the announced palettes, which usually contain a hundred or so colours.
